I was working with a plugin-provided jsfLibrary definition and had a build  problem (on my part) that accidentally omitted the actual jar file from my plugin.  Instead of just breaking that library contribution however this ended up taking down all JSF functionality with an uncaught exception.  The exception happened during jsf.core plugin startup:

org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in org.eclipse.jst.jsf.core.internal.JSFCorePlugin.start() of bundle org.eclipse.jst.jsf.core.
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.startActivator(BundleContextImpl.java:1018)

	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker(BundleHost.java:346)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.start(AbstractBundle.java:260)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.util.SecureAction.start(SecureAction.java:400)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseLazyStarter.postFindLocalClass(EclipseLazyStarter.java:111)

and was caused by:

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.Activator.getURLConverter(Activator.java:313)

Some hardening is needed to prevent plugin activation failure due to missing (or just typoed) files.  Also, is it really necessary to force the registry loading directly from plugin.start()?
This should be resolved in the IBuild for this week (I20070507).  Note also that we are no longer loading the registry during plugin startup.
